Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Powerhouse: An Integrated End-Use Tied Solar Thermal and Power System
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project aims to test the feasibility of a residential-scale, integrated mechanical system that supplies all energy needs of a low energy home, including heating, cooling, hot water, and power with 100% site-generated, renewable energy. If proven feasible, the system is expected to be cost-competitive with common existing HVAC (heating, ventilation, and air-conditioning) systems on an installed cost basis. Phase I of this project will focus on the supply of thermal end uses including cooking, domestic hot water, and space heating through a combination of solar energy and thermal storage. The broader impact of this Phase I research is to make carbon-neutral living a practical, affordable, and widely available option. The technology has the potential to leverage deep penetration of renewable energy into the nation's electric power system, reduce carbon emissions of the power sector, and support cost-effective, risk-aware infrastructure investments by electric utilities in the long term. In addition, the commercialization of the proposed integrated mechanical system could expand the number of sites deemed to be appropriate for renewable energy, improve access to affordable housing in general, and create job opportunities in green construction.


This project will test the feasibility of an integrated mechanical and power system to achieve a zero carbon home at zero incremental cost. Two components have been identified as being critical to the system-level cost efficiencies of the proposed system and will be investigated in Phase I: (1) a novel, convenient, indoor solar cooker and (2) a low-cost, roof-integrated, solar thermal collector with high-efficiency operation in space heating mode. The research targets include demonstration of a new means of cooking using stored thermal energy; construction of a solar thermal collector prototype suitable for cold climates that costs less than half that of glazed flat plate collectors, and development of control logic for thermal and electrical loads to meet power access and comfort expectations of the U.S. market. The project will test the cooking quality and cooking times of a new solar cooking method and build a first prototype cooker; prototype and measure the efficiency of the new solar thermal collector; develop a dynamic simulation of the system as part of an ultra-low energy home to test scheduling of load controls; and project the economics of the proposed system.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The aim of Phase I research was to determine the feasibility of the proposed PowerhouseTM system to meet all household energy demands for heating, cooling, domestic hot water, cooking, and power of a modestly sized, super-insulated home using a few novel components – a low-cost, roof-integrated solar thermal collector; in-floor thermal storage, and an indoor solar cooker – alongside a conventional PV array, limited battery storage, and a control system. If successfully brought to market within the target installed cost of half that of other solar-plus-batteries options, the Powerhouse technology could shift the way consumers think about their relationship to power infrastructure and offer a compelling way for people to invest in their security, the stability of the grid, and the environment. In addition, it has the potential to leverage deep penetration of renewable energy into the nation’s electric power system, reduce carbon emissions of the power sector, and support cost-effective, risk-aware infrastructure investments in the long term. Commercialization of the proposed system could improve access to affordable housing, in general, and create job opportunities in green construction within the $22 billion small homes market segment, which produces approximately 180,000 new units annually.

Phase I included prototyping, dynamic simulation, and cost analysis of system components. The research found that the new solar thermal collector, when integrated with thermal storage in a 850 square foot Passive House, was sufficient to provide all of the home’s space heating and cooling needs as well as 97.2% of domestic hot water energy demand without use of a backup system when simulated in a Lexington, Kentucky climate. In addition, the solar cooker was found to have comparable cook times for many foods relative to a conventional range oven and to meet 97.1% of household cooking demand without backup when simulated over the course of a year. The model of the control system demonstrated that a small, 2.4 kW photovoltaic array was sufficient to provide power for more than 95% of the home’s annual electrical loads using only a small battery for backup power. Although the cost of the Powerhouse system as a whole is estimated to be higher than the original target, the research was able to demonstrate the feasibility of the proposed performance specifications within a price range expected to be competitive in the general housing market.
